newsitem.title: JAPAN: Fire at Japan nuclear fuel plant soon put out.
newsitem.headline: Fire at Japan nuclear fuel plant soon put out.

text.p: A small fire broke out at a nuclear fuel reprocessing plant north of Tokyo on Tuesday morning, but it was soon extinguished and there was no damage to the environment, the operator of the plant said.

The fire at Power Reactor and Nuclear Fuel Development Corp's (PNC) Tokaimura plant in Ibaraki Prefecture, north of Tokyo, broke out at 10.08 a.m. (0108 GMT) but was put out about 15 minutes later, a spokesman for the state-run firm said.
There were no injuries, he said, adding that he could not provide any information on the impact on the firm's operations or the cost of the damage until an investigation was completed.
PNC has a prototype fast-breeder reactor, "Monju", operations of which have been suspended since an accident in December 1995 when sodium coolant leaked from the reactor.
No damage was caused to the environment in that incident, but the operators are still investigating the cause.
Revelations of an attempt to cover up the scale of the incident increased public distrust of Japan's nuclear policy.
Japan relies on nuclear reactors for about 32 percent of its electricity needs and currently ships the bulk of its nuclear waste to Europe to be reprocessed.
